sen.j: 油坊（あぶらぼう）は、滋賀県や京都府に伝わる怪火、または亡霊。
sen.e: Abura-bo is a strange light or a ghost known in Shiga prefecture and Kyoto prefecture.

sen.j: 名称は、油を盗んだ僧侶がこれに化けたという伝承に由来する。
sen.e: The origin of the name comes from a folk tale about a Buddhist monk who stole oil then turned himself into it.

sen.j: 滋賀県では、野洲郡欲賀村（現・野洲市）に、晩春から夏にかけて油坊という怪火が現れたと伝えらており、比叡山の灯油を盗んだ僧侶が変化したものといわれた。
sen.e: In Shiga prefecture, a strange light called abura-bo was said to appear from the end of spring through summer in Hoshika village, Yasu district (the present Yasu city), and it was said to be a Buddhist monk who had stolen lamp oil from Mt.Hiei then turned himself into it.

sen.j: 江戸時代の怪談本『古今百物語評判』では、名は「油盗人」（あぶらぬすびと）とされている。
sen.e: "Kokon Hyaku Monogatari Hyo‎ban (One Hundred Strange and Weird Tales of Past and Present)", a collection of ghost stories in Edo period, named it "Abura-nusubito" (an oil-thief).

sen.j: このような怪火は京都府にも現れたといい、寛政時代の雑書『諸国里人談』によれば比叡山の西麓にも現れたという。
sen.e: It is said that a similar strange light appeared in Kyoto prefecture, and according to "Shokoku rijindan"(Tales collected from village people), a book on miscellaneous subjects in the Kansei era, and that it also appeared at the western foot of Mt.Hiei.
sen.cmt: 原文には「諸国里人談」は寛政期の書物とありますが、確認したところ寛保期（1741年から1743年）の書物でした。ひとまず原文のまま訳しております。

sen.j: また、滋賀県愛知郡 (滋賀県)愛荘町の金剛寺では、油坊は油を手にした霊とされる。
sen.e: Furthermore, abura-bo is regarded as a ghost with oil in his hand at Kongo-ji temple in Aisho town, Echi district, Shiga prefecture.

sen.j: こちらにも野洲郡のものと似た伝承があり、寺に灯油を届ける役目を持つ僧侶が、遊ぶ金欲しさに灯油を盗んで金を作ったが、遊びに行く前に急病で命を落としてしまい、それ以来、寺の山門に霊となって現れるようになったという。
sen.e: It has a folk tale similar to the one in Yasu district; a Buddhist monk, who had had the duty of delivering lamp oil to the temple, stole the oil and made money for his love of having a good time, however, a sudden attack of illness took his life before he went out to have fun, and since then his ghost would appear at the temple gate.
